title: The Easiest Ways to Stop GIFs on Your Web Browser

steps.title: Find a GIF blocker extension for Chrome or Edge.
steps.content: Find a GIF blocker extension for Chrome or Edge. There is no setting that allows you to stop GIF animations in Google Chrome or Microsoft Edge. However, there are a few animated image-blocking extensions in each browser's associated store that you can download for free. Here are a few examples: GIF Blocker - This is the featured GIF blocker extension on the Chrome Web Store and Microsoft Edge extensions page. We will be using this extension in these examples Animation Policy - You only need to run this extension once and you can use it to set a policy that blocks all GIF animations (Chrome only). Photosensitivity Video Blocker - This extension is designed for people with video photosensitivity. It blocks GIFs and videos from auto-playing in your web browser (Chrome only). Alternatively you can go to the Chrome Web Store or Microsoft Edge Extensions Search Page and use the search bar to search for GIF blockers. However, be aware that some older extensions may not be supported anymore.

steps.title: Add the extension to your web browser.
steps.content: Add the extension to your web browser. To download an extension for Chrome or Edge, go to the extension's download page and click the Add to Chrome or Add to Edge button at the top of the extension's download page, then follow the on-screen instructions.

steps.title: Pin the extension to your browser for easy access.
steps.content: Pin the extension to your browser for easy access. To make sure you can start the animated GIF blocker in your browser, click the jigsaw puzzle piece icon at the top-right corner to view a list of all installed extensions, then click the pushpin icon next to the extension. Now you'll see the extension's icon in the tray at the upper-right corner of your browser, to the right of the URL bar.

steps.title: Right-click the extension's icon and click Options.
steps.content: Right-click the extension's icon and click Options . This will open another window so you can change how the extension works. If you're using a Mac, press Ctrl while you click to right-click.

steps.title: Click the boxes next to the options you want to block.
steps.content: Click the boxes next to the options you want to block. For example, many sites rely on WebP animations to display login or other important information, so you should uncheck that one if you want those animations to work. To make it so GIFs don't play automatically, check the option to "Block 'GIF' animation type." The options will vary by extension.

steps.title: Click Save Options.
steps.content: Click Save Options . This saves the settings you selected and applies them.

steps.title: Go to a website with GIFs.
steps.content: Go to a website with GIFs. Now that you have a GIF blocker, any animated GIFs on the page will no longer load. If you want to see one of the GIFs that didn't load, right-click or control-click on it and select Show this Image .

steps.title: Open your iOS Settings .
steps.content: Open your iOS Settings . Tap the app icon that resembles two gears to open the Settings menu. If you don't want GIFs to play automatically on websites in Safari or in the Messages app, you can turn them off by making a quick change in your Accessibility settings.

steps.title: Tap Accessibility.
steps.content: Tap Accessibility . You'll need to scroll down to find this menu option.

steps.title: Tap Motion.
steps.content: Tap Motion . You'll see options to reduce motion.

steps.title: Turn on Reduce Motion.
steps.content: Turn on Reduce Motion . When this option is on, it reduces the motion of animated items, such as icon effects.

steps.title: Turn off Auto-Play Animated Images.
steps.content: Turn off Auto-Play Animated Images . Animated images like GIFs will no longer automatically play in Messages or Safari.

steps.title: Turn off Auto-play Message Effects.
steps.content: Turn off Auto-play Message Effects . This stops full-screen message effects from automatically playing in the Messages app. However, you can still view them by tapping them.

steps.title: Turn off Auto-play Video Previews.
steps.content: Turn off Auto-play Video Previews . This stops video thumbnail previews such as the ones you see in the App Store.

steps.title: Turn on Dim flashing lights.
steps.content: Turn on Dim flashing lights . If you have photosensitivity you may want to turn this option on. This automatically dims content when flashing or strobing lights are detected. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Open System Settings.
steps.content: Open System Settings. Click the Apple logo and select System Settings . If you don't want GIFs and other animations to play automatically in Safari and other apps on your Mac, you can disable auto-play in your Accessibility settings.

steps.title: Click Acessibility.
steps.content: Click Acessibility . It's next to a blue icon on the sidebar of the menu.

steps.title: Click Display.
steps.content: Click Display . This will give you more options.

steps.title: Turn on Reduce Motion.
steps.content: Turn on Reduce Motion . This reduces all motion on your screen. It reduces animated effects and transitions.

steps.title: Turn off Auto-play animated images.
steps.content: Turn off Auto-play animated images . This will prevent messages in Messenger or websites in Safari from automatically playing repeated images like GIFs.

steps.title: Turn on Dim flashing lights.
steps.content: Turn on Dim flashing lights . If you have photosensitivity, you may want to turn this on. This automatically dims animations when flashing or strobing lights are detected on screen. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Type "about:config" in the URL field of Firefox and press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type " about:config " in the URL field of Firefox and press ↵ Enter . You'll see a warning to "Proceed with Caution" since any changes you make here can affect Firefox's performance and security.

steps.title: Click Accept the Risk and Continue.
steps.content: Click Accept the Risk and Continue . This opens a page with some hidden settings.

steps.title: Click Show All.
steps.content: Click Show All . It's the button at the top of the page. This shows all preferences.

steps.title: Type "animation" in the search bar.
steps.content: Type " animation " in the search bar. You'll see a list of matching preferences as you type.

steps.title: Double-click the "image.animation_mode" listing and enter none.
steps.content: Double-click the "image.animation_mode" listing and enter none . This field says "Default" before you change it. When you change it to "None", animations will no longer play when webpages load in Firefox. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Download and install GIF blocking extensions.
steps.content: Download and install GIF blocking extensions. If you don't want to mess with the configuration preferences, you can download Firefox add-ons that prevent animated images and GIFs from automatically playing. Some of the following are extensions you can use to block GIF animations: GIF Blocker - The most popular GIF-blocking extension for Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge is also available for Firefox. Toggle Image Animation - This add-on places a toggle switch in the menu bar that allows you to toggle animations on and off.

steps.title: Open the Settings menu .
steps.content: Open the Settings menu . To do so, swipe down from the top of the screen. Then tap the gear icon in the upper-right corner.

steps.title: Tap Accessibility.
steps.content: Tap Accessibility . It's in the Settings menu. This allows you to modify accessibility options for vision, hearing, and dexterity limitations.

steps.title: Tap Vision Enhancements.
steps.content: Tap Vision Enhancements . It's near the top of the Accessibility menu. On some Android models, this may read as "Visibility enhancements."

steps.title: Tap the toggle switch next to "Reduce animations."
steps.content: Tap the toggle switch next to "Reduce animations." This option reduces animations and transitions across your entire Android device. [4] X Research source
